awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Jonathan Wang is "Representation theory, automorphic forms, and Langlands program using classical and geometric harmonic analysis." The host institution for the fellowship is Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Roman Bezrukavnikov.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the origins of automorphic L-functions, which are central objects at the heart of modern number theory. The main outcome of the project was the discovery of a unifying mechanism that tied all previous constructions together, and generated a new source for future constructions. Along the way, the project developed novel tools for studying this problem using techniques from other branches of mathematics such as representation theory and algebraic geometry. Moreover, the discoveries and tools from this project initiate some of the first steps towards an entirely new research area: proving relationships between L-functions in number theory and certain dualities in string theory in mathematical physics.


In addition, the project dedicated efforts to teaching undergraduates how to effectively communicate about mathematics, both verbally and in writing. As a result, students developed strong technical presentation skills and the ability to write clear technical documents explaining mathematical content to both experts and non-experts. These skills will be very broadly applicable and benefit the scientific community at large. This project also helped to mentor individual undergraduates and high school students in cutting-edge math research projects. The students were introduced to the forefront of modern research, and then mentored to build up the skills necessary to contribute new discoveries to the contemporary literature.
